_prev_prog_3.PC_OtherType: Fill alarm at 80% with auto. Shutoff at 85%, min. Class 1 Div. 1 electric w/in 5 ft. of all transfer (truck offloading) points w/Class 1 Div. 2 from 5-15 feet, Class 1 Div. 2 w/in 15 ft. of remainder
_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Hydrocarbon detectors tied to terminal shutdown, flow monitoring, temperature, pressure, & liquid level indicators

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RELEASE POLICIES

Blanchard Terminal Company LLC (Blanchard) - Jacksonville Terminal is a refined petroleum products distributor. The Jacksonville Terminal is an onshore, light products, bulk petroleum storage terminal used in the storage and distribution of petroleum products to retail and commercial end-users in the vicinity of Jacksonville, FL. The Terminal handles and stores various grades of unleaded gasoline, low-sulfur diesel, butane, ethanol, and various other petroleum based additives.

Blanchard - Jacksonville Terminal in Jacksonville, FL is committed to operating and maintaining processes in a safe, reliable and environmentally sound manner. Blanchard believes that excellent performance in health, safety, and the environment goes hand in hand with operating reliably, and that outstanding HES performance is of paramount importance.

The Jacksonville Terminal is designed, operated and maintained in a manner that protects the environment, as well as the health and safety of its employees, contractors and the community.  Blanchard promotes health, safety, and the environment through programs of awareness, compliance, prevention and protection. These programs include a combination of accidental release prevention and emergency response planning. This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that Blanchard has designed and implemented, including:

A. A description of the facility and the use of regulated substances;
B. An overview of the accidental release prevention programs;
C. A five-year accident history for accidental releases of regulated chemicals;
D. An overview of the emergency response program; and
E. An overview of planned changes to improve safety.

A. STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The primary function of the Jacksonville Terminal is to act as a refined petroleum distribution facility. The butane blending process has been classified as

an RMP Program Level 3.  No Program 1 or 2 processes containing regulated substances were identified. By virtue of the flammable effects associated with butane, it is necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling butane to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to employee health, and to minimize the threat and impact to nearby members of the community along with the surrounding environment. Safety at the Facility depends upon the manner in which butane is handled as well as the various safety/control devices incorporated into the design of the process.  Furthermore, comprehensive training is provided to employees, which reinforces the safety policies and procedures of the Jacksonville Terminal.

The facility maintains fixed inventories of butane. Butane is received by truck (transports) and stored in one (1) storage vessel. Specifically, liquefied butane is off-loaded by truck for storage under pressure.  The butane is pumped to blending skids (x2) for direct injection into regular/blend grade and premium unleaded gasoline lines feeding the site gasoline truck-loading racks. Injection quantities are controlled via an injection skid and auto-analyzer. Process safety controls include excess flow valves, low-melting point (<250 degrees Fahrenheit) fusible elements(fail safe valves), 85% fill shutoff on the vessel, emergency shutoff devices on the system and video display terminal, line thermal reliefs, and grounding/interlock devices.  This process is remotely monitored "24/7". Access to the Jacksonville Terminal is restricted to authorized employees, management personnel and authorized contractors/visitors.

B. GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC
PREVENTION MEASURES

Blanchard's accidental release prevention and emergency planning and response programs help effectively manage the hazards posed by the Terminal's regulated substance to its employees, the public, and the environment. The covered pro

ue. A Facility Response Plan (FRP) is in place to inform employees what to do in case of a release, fire, and to notify emergency responders when there is a need for a response.

Blanchard - Jacksonville Terminal complies with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) Accident Prevention Rules (40 CFR Part 68 Subpart D), the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard and associated 14 elements (29 CFR Part 1910.119), and all applicable state (includes voluntary participation in the Florida Division of Emergency Management Risk Management Program) and local laws and regulations. The butane blending system is designed, constructed, and maintained in accordance with NFPA #58 and the manufacturer's (Energy Transfer Partners, L.P.), instructions and recommendations.

In the event of an emergency involving the Jacksonville Terminal butane blending system, it is the policy of the Facility to initially contact the Jacksonville Fire & Rescue and request their assistance via "MAPLINE".  The Facility maintains a trained (annually) incipient fire capability. The Terminal's emergency response plans are coordinated with the Jacksonville Fire & Rescue, and Duval County Emergency Management.

Blanchard also maintain a relationship with the Jacksonville Fire & Rescue. Tours and drills with members of local emergency response organizations are held periodically. These tours and drills enable the public emergency responders to become familiar with the hazards, equipment, resources and personnel in the terminal.

E. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Blanchard is continually striving to make the Jacksonville Terminal the safest and most reliable workplace possible for its employees, neighbors and community.

In an effort to improve and promote system safety, Blanchard looks for, and seeks employee input, on process safety improvements. Blanchard is a responsible care facility accomplished via routine (annual) complia

nce elements (this is in addition to the required triennial audit).  Blanchard also follows API 754 recommended practices for reporting, tracking and evaluating leading and lagging indicators of process safety program performance.
